utterances: Thank you.
And you can weigh in with your thoughts at our blog npr.org/daydreaming.
There's a posting there, ""Bail out, yes or no."" Tell us what you want the government to do.
Suzan Johnson Cook once served as a domestic policy advisor to President Bill Clinton.
Now, she's the editor of Sister 2 Sister magazine, and a senior pastor at the Believers Christian Fellowship in New York City.
Her congregants call her Dr. Sujay.

She's written a new book called, ""Moving Up: Dr. Sujay's Ten Steps to Turning Your Life Around and Getting to the Top!"" NPR's Tony Cox sat down with Johnson Cook to talk about transforming your mental and spiritual attitude.
Suzan, welcome to the show.
It's nice to have you on.
Thank you so much for having me.
It's a pleasure to be here.
Your book is called ""Moving Up,"" and it lists ten steps people can take to turn their lives around.
A few examples of those steps are titled, Speak Up, Look Up, Book Up, Listen Up, Cheer Up.
But the first chapter is called Stand Up.
Is there a reason that Stand Up is first?

It is because what it is that you have to make a declaration, really a command to yourself, that you're going to change your posture, that you're ready to go from laying down to standing up, from sitting on the sidelines to going to the frontlines.
And, so, it is a command.
It says, I am ready.
I am ready to make a stand.
Any time you're ready for a change, there has to be a posture move.
And, so, it's a wonderful, wonderful way to begin the book because it's a wonderful way to begin the next phase of your life.
You know, you've written inspirational books before as part of your ministry.
Why this one?
You know what?
This one, first of all, reads so much easier for me.
I always am telling my publishers, you know, when people are stressed out or want inspiration, they don't want to have to go through 400 pages and try to get a, you know, thesaurus and everything.
I'm pessimistic about it because I don't see that happening.
I don't see any mechanism for that happening, especially when you look at colleges.
You see how much pushback you get to compensating athletes.
But at the same time, you don't see a great deal of interest in educating athletes.

Cosco, the Chinese shipping company, won the chance to send one of its ultra-large vessels through the new expanded locks, which are longer, wider and deeper than the original ones completed back in 1914.
And with less than two months before opening day, hundreds of workers are out in full force.
(SOUNDBITE OF CONSTRUCTION)
At the far end of one of three huge chambers of the new locks, a backhoe scrapes up the remaining boulders at the water's edge.
Waldo Chan of the Canal Authority says there's only 3 percent of the project left to finish.
Exactly.
They're just putting on the final touches.
Exactly, the work they're doing right now.
It's been a long haul for Panama to get this far.
Construction started nearly a decade ago, back in September of 2007.
Cost overruns, labor fights and bitter legal disputes delayed opening by more than a year.
Nils Haupt of Hapag-Lloyd, one of the world's largest shipping companies, says the industry can now use its so-called neo-Panamax ships.
Those mega vessels hold almost three times the number of containers that fit on the biggest ships allowed now through the canal.
You know, if you have bigger ships, you know, you can just take one big ship instead of two smaller ships, which is - for the shipping line is a big advantage.
But Steve Fitzroy, a transportation consultant at the Economic Development Research Group, says the new canal opens at a financially difficult time for the shipping industry.
Vessel operators have brought on a lot of large, new vessels.
They're much bigger than have been operating in the past.
And demand is weak because of global economic concerns.
Add to that the concern over water.
This year's El Nino has left Panama with a longer-than-normal dry season.
Last month, the Canal Authority had to restrict ship crossings through the old locks because of the lack of water.
Geological engineer J.
David Rogers of Missouri University of Science and Technology says the expansion's new locks have built-in reserve base to save water.
And he says engineers built a new dam to allow for more water storage in the wetter years.
J.
DAVID ROGERS: Because it's a precious resource, even in a place like Panama, where it rains constantly (laughter).
(SOUNDBITE OF SCHOOLBELL)
For now, while the country waits for the new canal to finally open its gates, schoolkids continue to flock to the old locks.
(Speaking Spanish).
Eleven-year-old Riczaery Ramos says it's fantastic and beautiful to watch the big ships.
If all goes according to schedule, she'll soon get to see even bigger ones, some of the largest in the world, come through her country.
Carrie Kahn, NPR News, Panama.
Russian President Vladimir Putin shocked the world last fall when he deployed warplanes to Syria.
He shocked the world again last night when he announced he is largely withdrawing them.
Putin said Russia's objectives have been achieved.
Let's talk now with Andrew Tabler.
He's a Syria expert with The Washington Institute for Near East Policy, and he joins us via Skype.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Let me start by asking what those Russian objectives are - military, political, both - that Putin says he's achieved.
Well, that's a very good question.
Of course, President Putin intervened through the Syrian government in Syria to fight terrorism and terrorist groups in the country, including ISIS, which they held out as a major enemy.
But their military operations in the country didn't just target ISIS.
It mostly targeted the moderate rebels.
And now, somehow, despite the fact that Assad only gained back 5 percent of Syrian territory, Putin's declaring victory and sending his jets at least partially home.
Well, could it be that he did indeed prop up President Assad at a time when he was not looking in such good shape?
He did.
And Russia played a weak hand in - at least in terms of Assad's domestic standing - very, very well.
But the war in Syria is far from over.
I don't think the Assad regime expected this.
And it puts a lot of the military burden back on the Assad regime and its allies to keep their head above water.
You mean expected this mostly withdrawal.
Correct.
And it is just an unusual twist on the first day in Geneva when the U.N.
was meeting with representatives of the Assad regime for that - for the Russians to suddenly pack up and at least partially take their military hardware home.
Well, let me ask to get another perspective here.
President Obama predicted the Russian deployment to Syria would lead to a, quote, ""quagmire."" That hasn't quite happened.
No, it hasn't.
Russia's not necessarily stuck in Syria.

But I think this decision indicates that the - that in Moscow there is considerable concern about the regime's lack of manpower and that the regime will not make concessions - political concessions - that can rebuild the country without facing the hard facts in the battlefield.
And I think President Putin has just delivered those hard facts back to President Assad much more than he anticipated.
Well, just briefly, Putin did say part of the reason for the withdrawal was that there's a cease-fire in place and peace talks have begun in Geneva.
What then do you see - where do you see this going?
Well, it's a good question.
It's only a cessation of hostility, so the war, including Russian airstrikes, continue.
That's the strange part.
Also ISIS still controls about 50 percent of Syrian territory.
It's an unusual twist.
We'll have to wait and see what happens in the coming days and what the Russian ""withdrawal,"" quote, from Syria really means.
Well, we do have just about 30 more seconds.
What does this mean to Assad?
This is a question of black body versus black brain.
And in the United States, the black body has always been what's been compensated - whether you can sing, whether you can dance, whether you can - you know, you can - when you work manually.
That's what we care about.
That's the currency.
Malawi is it.
That's right.
They move from thinking about it to doing it.
What we call from the contemplation stage to the action stage.
Mm-hmm.
And you also report that a few simple things can move people from the contemplation to the actual state.
And one of those you report is making a phone call to a friend who's got the resolution.
You say as few as three phone calls will get them going.
The buddy system works.
